bestBHT.bht: The religious leaders approached Jesus, mentioning that Moses wrote unto us, in Deuteronomy 25:5 where the substance of what follows is contained. (Source) They referred to a law instructing a man's brother to marry his widow if he dies without children, ensuring the continuation of the family name and inheritance. They aimed to test Jesus by presenting a scenario involving the implications of this law.

John Gill: Saying, master, Moses wrote unto us, in Deuteronomy 25:5 where the substance of what follows is contained, though not in express words."
If any man's brother die, having a wife, and he die without children, that his brother should take his wife, and raise up seed unto his brother.

The meaning of which is, that if a man died without issue, and left a wife behind him, his next brother, if unmarried, was to marry his wife, and the first child born of her, was to be reckoned the deceased's, and to inherit his estate.

bhtAttempts.bht: According to the first-tier commentary, when the religious leaders approached Jesus and said, Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man's brother dies, having a wife but no children, the man must take the widow and raise up offspring for his brother. [Luke 20:28 ESV], they were referring to the law stated in Deuteronomy 25:5. The second-tier commentary further explains that this law mandated that if a man died without children, his brother was to marry his wife and the first child born of them would be considered the deceased's and inherit his estate.

When the religious leaders approached Jesus, they quoted Moses from Deuteronomy 25:5, sharing a law that stated if a man's brother died without children, the living brother would marry the widow and the first child born would inherit the deceased brother's estate. This practice ensured the continuation of the family line and the preservation of inheritance. The leaders wanted to test Jesus by presenting a scenario involving the implications of this law.

When the religious leaders approached Jesus, citing Moses from Deuteronomy 25:5, they brought up a law that required a man's brother to marry his widow if he died childless, and the first child born would inherit the deceased brother's estate. This law ensured the continuation of the family line and the preservation of inheritance. The leaders aimed to test Jesus by presenting a scenario involving the implications of this law.

The religious leaders approached Jesus, mentioning that Moses wrote unto us, in Deuteronomy 25:5 where the substance of what follows is contained. (Source) They referred to a law instructing a man's brother to marry his widow if he dies without children, ensuring the continuation of the family name and inheritance. They aimed to test Jesus by presenting a scenario involving the implications of this law.

The religious leaders approached Jesus, quoting Deuteronomy 25:5, where it states that if a man's brother dies without children, the living brother should marry the widow and raise up offspring for his brother. This law ensured the continuation of the deceased brother's lineage and preserved his inheritance. The leaders sought to challenge Jesus by presenting a hypothetical situation that involved the application of this law.
